name: Haskell
characterSketch: The beautifully dressed philosopher who can't find their car keys. Haskell writes the most elegant code in any language, then spends 45 minutes explaining why IO is actually a monad.

name: Rust
characterSketch: The overprotective friend who's always right. Rust won't let you make mistakes, and you'll resent it until you realize every error it caught would have been a 3am production incident.

name: Elixir
characterSketch: The jazz musician who studied classical. Elixir takes Erlang's battle-tested concurrency and wraps it in syntax so pleasant you forget you're building distributed systems that never go down.

name: Kotlin
characterSketch: The diplomat who made peace between Java and good taste. Kotlin looked at decades of JVM pain and said 'what if we just... didn't do that?' and everyone agreed.

name: Swift
characterSketch: The architect who redesigned the entire house because the kitchen drawer was 2mm off. Swift pursues perfection with Apple-level obsession, and the result is a language that feels inevitable.

name: Python
characterSketch: Everyone's first love and nobody's last. Python is the golden retriever of languages: friendly, eager to please, and somehow equally at home in a data science lab or a teenager's first project.

name: Ruby
characterSketch: The poet who became a startup founder. Ruby optimized for developer happiness before that was a marketing term, and Matz's humanity shines through every design decision.

name: TypeScript
characterSketch: The responsible older sibling who cleans up JavaScript's messes. TypeScript proves that the best way to fix a language is to build a better one on top and pretend the old one doesn't exist.

name: Scala
characterSketch: The PhD student who insists on explaining category theory at dinner parties. Scala has the intellectual firepower of ten languages, which is precisely the problem.

name: Clojure
characterSketch: The Zen master who sees through your abstractions. Clojure distills programming to data, functions, and immutability, then watches smugly as your mutable-state codebase catches fire.

name: F#
characterSketch: The brilliant cousin nobody invites to parties. F# does everything right on the .NET platform, writes more elegant code than C# ever could, and wonders why nobody's paying attention.

name: OCaml
characterSketch: The quiet genius in the corner who invented half of modern type theory and never got credit. OCaml's type system is a masterpiece; its ecosystem is an archaeology dig.

name: Go
characterSketch: The minimalist architect who removed every feature you loved and somehow built something better. Go proves that what you leave out matters more than what you put in.

name: C#
characterSketch: The corporate executive who secretly writes poetry. C# started as a Java clone in a suit, then quietly evolved into one of the most feature-complete languages ever designed.

name: Dart
characterSketch: The second-chance kid who found their calling in Flutter. Dart was nearly forgotten until mobile development gave it a purpose, and now it's living its best life painting pixels.

name: Julia
characterSketch: The prodigy who wants to be Python, R, and Fortran simultaneously. Julia solves the two-language problem by being fast enough for C programmers and readable enough for scientists.

name: Lua
characterSketch: The compact Swiss army knife that fits in any pocket. Lua is so small and embeddable that it powers everything from World of Warcraft to nginx configs without anyone noticing.

name: Zig
characterSketch: The systems programmer who looked at C and said 'I can fix this without adding complexity.' Zig is the rare language that removes footguns by making the right thing the easy thing.

name: Java
characterSketch: The enterprise middle manager who requires a meeting to schedule a meeting. Java turned verbosity into a virtue and AbstractSingletonProxyFactoryBean into a punchline.

name: JavaScript
characterSketch: The accidental emperor who conquered the world in 10 days. JavaScript was built as a toy, became the backbone of the internet, and still thinks '0' == 0 is reasonable.

name: C
characterSketch: The grizzled veteran who built the foundations everyone else stands on. C gives you a knife, a piece of rope, and unlimited trust -- the scars are your problem.

name: C++
characterSketch: The Swiss army chainsaw that's been accumulating features since 1979. C++ can do anything, which is exactly why most C++ code looks like it was written by a committee -- because it was.

name: PHP
characterSketch: The duct tape that holds 40% of the web together while everyone pretends it doesn't exist. PHP is the cockroach of programming: ugly, everywhere, and absolutely unkillable.

name: Perl
characterSketch: The cryptic wizard whose spells work perfectly but look like line noise. Perl proved that regular expressions are the answer to every problem, especially the ones they shouldn't be.

name: COBOL
characterSketch: The immortal bureaucrat who processes trillions of dollars daily and hasn't been updated since your parents were born. COBOL will outlive us all, running payroll in the afterlife.
